CatDescriptText: Mr. Kenneth E. Grimmet, Board of Education employee, Terrace Village and Mr. Joseph Frazier, electrician, Homewood, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 16, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think the so-called 'store-front' churches, and those who are known generally as 'self-styled preachers,' are an asset or a liability to the community." Mr. Kenneth E. Grimmet's answer reads: "Personally, I think that it's more or less an asset, because I think most are sincere and they truly believe in what they are doing."  Mr. Joseph Frazier's answer reads: "I wouldn't comment too much.  It depends on where it is and, also, depends on the pastor.  And that's regardless of whether its a big church or a store front.  Perhaps if it hadn't been for small churches, there wouldn't have been so many larg [sic] churches today.  And I think of John Wesley Church which began, not in a 'store front,' but in a field."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Kenneth E. Grimmet wearing striped cap, moustache, and dark pea coat, standing on sidewalk, Downtown; Portrait of Joseph Frazier wearing plaid shirt and jacket with corduroy collar and sleeves, standing in front of ribbed metal wall
